{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3604549,"name":"","username":"Tedzzy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/eb8c5e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-26T14:47:47.377Z","cooked":"

So I am investigating the design of the MK4 series and have found a peculiar design choice made by SDS. In the belt-driven turret for turning, the larger pulley appears to have 42 teeth; however, these teeth don’t seem to match the standard HTD 5M profile. I suspect this choice was made to accommodate the inner diameter of the bearing used on the turret, possibly due to machining limitations. Does anyone know how this works and why this choice was made? Additionally, how do I calculate the pitch diameter of this larger pulley, as it isn’t specified in SDS’s documentation as far as I know?

image934×624 57.1 KB

Your answer:

2910 MK2 Swerve Module Release FIRST
The tooth profile for that pulley is custom. It is based on HTD tooth profile, but is then heavily changed for easier, faster machining. The pulley has 20 teeth, but is equivalent in size to 60 tooth. With a 60 tooth pulley with that much belt wrap you really don’t need all the teeth. Here is a picture showing how the tooth profile engages the belt. [image]
